replication_study.hypothesis: Women will report higher agreement (higher Likert scores) on COVID-19 anxiety items (mh_anxiety_1 and mh_anxiety_3) than men in the Germany sample.

data_plan.source_type: Quantitative online survey via an ISO-certified online access panel
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Single wave fielded March 19–23, 2020; Germany adults (per original paper and post_registration.json). Dataset here contains observations labeled CountryofLiving == 'Germany'.
data_plan.sample_size: Approximately N=10,071 after restricting to binary gender with non-missing female indicator (from 10,192 total rows; female missing=121).
data_plan.access_details: Provided directly in replication_data folder as data_gerhold.csv; no additional access or credentials required.

qualification.explanation: This dataset is suitable because it captures the same target population (adults in Germany during the early COVID-19 period) and includes gender, anxiety items, and survey weights, allowing a replication of a key directional claim (women report higher fear/anxiety) using closely related measures.
qualification.similarity_to_original: Same country and context: Germany-only sample (CountryofLiving is Germany for all rows in data_gerhold.csv). The original paper reports a March 19–23, 2020 ISO-panel survey in Germany (original_paper.pdf, Section 2 Method and sample; post_registration.json original_study.data.wave_or_subset). The replication dataset includes gender and Likert-type mental health/anxiety items (mh_anxiety_1, mh_anxiety_3) which are proximal to the original constructs of worry/fear reported in original_paper.pdf Table 4 and the gender differences in Figure 2.
qualification.deviation_from_original: The original study reports specific worry/fear items and comprehensive coping scales (28 items) with Cronbach’s alpha, N=1242 after cleaning (original_paper.pdf; post_registration.json). The provided dataset contains only two anxiety items (mh_anxiety_1, mh_anxiety_3) and lacks the full coping battery, so we cannot reconstruct the exact coping scales or their reliability. The sample size (10,192 rows; 10,071 usable for binary gender) differs substantially from the original N=1242 (post_registration.json; original_paper.pdf), and the presence and magnitude of weights (weight_new) suggest a different weighting scheme; therefore, we normalize weights for analysis.

data_plan.notes: Columns observed: CountryofLiving (all Germany), gender (1/2/3), female (0/1 with some missing), mh_anxiety_1 and mh_anxiety_3 (Likert 1–5), weight_sample, weight_new (very large magnitudes). We normalize weights to mean 1 before WLS. Only binary gender observations (female_bin in {0,1}) are retained. The anxiety items are used as proxies for the original fear/worry constructs. No timestamps are available in this data; timing relies on original documentation.

steps: Filter to CountryofLiving == 'Germany' (all rows already match).
Construct binary female indicator: use existing female where available; otherwise map gender==2 to female=1 and gender==1 to female=0; drop others.
Normalize available survey weights (weight_new preferred; else weight_sample) to mean 1 to stabilize WLS.
For each anxiety item (mh_anxiety_1, mh_anxiety_3), compute unweighted group means by gender and Welch’s t-test for difference in means.
Estimate weighted gender difference using WLS (outcome ~ const + female_bin) with robust (HC1) standard errors.
planned_method.models: Welch’s two-sample t-test (unweighted); Weighted least squares (WLS) regression with robust (HC1) standard errors: outcome ~ const + female.
planned_method.control_variables: None (to align with bivariate gender comparisons reported in the original for fear/worry).

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Gender difference in mean Likert scores (female minus male); WLS coefficient on female_bin.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: Welch’s t-test for unweighted comparisons; robust t-test on WLS coefficient (HC1). Two-sided tests.

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion on variables used in each test (drop rows with missing female indicator or outcome).
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: Given two closely related primary outcomes, we will report uncorrected p-values (to mirror the original’s reporting style). As a robustness note, results can be interpreted with a Bonferroni threshold of 0.025 if desired.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Primary: p<0.05 (two-sided) and direction consistent with hypothesis (women higher). We report both unweighted Welch tests and weighted WLS estimates.

files.replication_data/replicate_gerhold__py.p: Entry-point script. Reads /app/data/data_gerhold.csv, constructs female_bin, normalizes weights, runs Welch t-tests and WLS with robust SEs for mh_anxiety_1 and mh_anxiety_3 against gender, and writes /app/data/replication_results.json.

codebase.notes: All IO uses /app/data. Dependencies: pandas, numpy, scipy, statsmodels. The script filters to binary gender only, normalizes weights to mean 1, and uses HC1 robust SEs for WLS.

analysis.instructions: 1) Ensure data file is present at /app/data/data_gerhold.csv. 2) Run: python replication_data/replicate_gerhold__py.py. 3) Inspect /app/data/replication_results.json for gender-difference estimates and p-values.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare directionality (female > male) and statistical significance (p-values) to the original paper’s claims (women more worried/afraid; original_paper.pdf Table 4 and Figure 2; post_registration.json results). Magnitude is not directly comparable due to different items; focus on sign and significance.
